channel.title: My Lawnmower
channel.description:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BCaKFlU_fnI
A few months ago, I was making an air engine in engineering class at school and I decided to make something bigger and better, that could run on steam. After a few minutes searching for steam engines, I noticed that you could convert an old lawn mower to run on air. So I went to the shed and found an old dead lawn mower, stripped it down and cleaned all the internals. After I took the head off, the gasket broke, so it was leaking air all over the place. I decided to try epoxy glue as a head gasket. This worked very well and stopped all leaks. I then took the old cam out and welded two new lobes on to the opposite sides that the original ones were on, this created a 4 lobed cam, making the engine into a two-stroke. I then ran air into the engine through where the carburettor used to be and it ran 'alrightish' - about 200 rpm. After that, I found an old pipe lying around which had a 70mm interior diameter, I cut that down to 350mm and found a big sheet of 5mm steel plate. Using a plasma cutter, I cut them into circles, then used the grinder to make them smooth. I then spent some time welding them to the ends of the pipe (I drilled an outlet hole on the pipe first so it wouldn't explode.) Once it was welded and I was happy that there were no leaks, I welded a small pipe onto the outlet hole so I could hook on the steam delivery hose. I then made a flange for the input (old exhaust) port on the engine, again, I used epoxy glue to seal the gaps. Then I gave the engine a test run, it ran fairly slowly even though the fire was about 3 times hotter than the one in this video. In my attempts to make the original cam work better, I managed to snap it in the middle. So that gave me a bit of a problem to solve. I returned to the shed and found another dead lawn mower. I dismantled the engine and, to my surprise, the gear and the lobes of the cam were made of plastic. I tried to super glue layers of plastic on to make new lobes, but they kept ripping off, I had to find a better way to make it work. I took the cam to school, and after a few minutes talking to the teacher, I decided to get some 25mm mild steel bar and turn it to the correct sizes in the lathe. Once I finally managed to get the bar to the right size,I drilled a half inch hole through the middle. Then I used the milling machine to flatten off opposing sides. It then started to resemble a cam. There was still a lot of work to be done. I then used the bench grinder to roughly shape the lobes. Then, with the angle grinder, I made the lobes a bit more correct in shape. After that, I spent about 4 or 5 hours fine tuning the cam, modifying the con-rod, and positioning it on the cam shaft. It could still be slightly better, but right now it is running very well. Also, the engine runs backwards now, I cannot rotate the cam 90 degrees because it then hits the con-rod. So I just welded some sharp plates onto the blade so it cuts when running in reverse. (About 2000 RPM at 100 PSI of air, and it idles at about 200 RPM at 20 PSI (through a small jet, it might go faster with a bigger hose.) So yea, it can cut a little bit of grass how it is at the moment running on steam. The next thing will be to make a better boiler and a more efficient firebox. I might also put a barbecue on it so you can make lunch while mowing the lawns.
All in all, the engine has been opened over 100 times in the last two months.
Please post comments and tell your friends about this video!

item.title: My Lawnmower
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

UPDATE:

I replaced the engine on my lawnmower. I decided to swap it because the threads were just too far gone on the old engine to make it worthwhile to use decent gaskets. I had to swap the cam, pushrods and bottom end of the con-rod into the new engine (was still an old engine and couldn’t run on petrol at all). It took about an hour and a half to get it all done (it was fiddly work when I couldn’t be screwed to take the sump plate off completely - that takes about 20 mins to remove a certain part to get it off). I used some gasket maker from the neighbour to seal the intake flange. I’m not too sure if the gasket will hold, the neighbour says that the gasket maker is pretty shitty with pressures, and I run the engine at 100 PSI.

So yea, on Saturday I will try to run it again.

[hr]


That is it running with the new engine.

Read full topic

item.title: My Lawnmower
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

Yea, my property is flat.

UPDATE:

Had it running this morning, it started to gain pressure almost instantly.

I cut a decently long strip of grass with it.

Then, as it started to run out of water, I made a video of it running down from 90 PSI (it could barely make any pressure near the end.)

UPDATE:

I filled it up, lit it up then cooked my lunch on top of it while it was warming up. Got it to hold steady at 80 PSI, then cut the lawn (only about 20% was left to cut). After I finished cutting the lawn, I got bored so I just let the engine run at full speed - cycling through the speeds for the fun aswell). Then my dad came home to take a look and I turned it on to full speed. It was running perfectly for about 20 seconds then it was like ‘WUSSH’ and lost all power and stopped. First I thought the blade came loose, so I checked that. It was still tight. Then I checked to see if the valves were being lifted. They were. I then removed the spark plug hole bung to see if the piston/con-rod broke. That was still working correctly. So that just left the inlet manifold gasket to check. I knew that it would fail some time in the next day or two because it was already leaking. So I pulled the inlet manifold (a plate with two bolts and the copper feed pipe coming out of it). When I did that, the Epoxy Glue gasket fell out in like 3 bits.

I think the reason that it broke was because I didn’t clean the old Epoxy Glue gasket off the surface correctly last time that I took the manifold off and the glue couldn’t form a very good bond. The head gasket made from Epoxy Glue seems to be holding up perfectly well still.

So yea. It is a 5 minute job to fix it as soon as I get some new Epoxy Glue to seal it all back up.

No video sorry.

Read full topic

item.title: My Lawnmower
item.dc:creator: @runescape3dude runescape3dude
item.description:
@runescape3dude wrote:

Steam Engine Lawnmower Running Nicely

With the new (huge) boiler, it runs for a very long time and runs fairly fast. It goes as well as a normal lawnmower at 50 PSI, tomorrow I will get another 4 M of copper piping to make it run better still.

It even cut grass!!!

Didn’t weigh it yet, but it is easy to push along, unless you want to go really slow - then it is pretty hard to push over the individual lumps…

It ran for about 40 mins on the half tank of water, I haven’t checked how much is left, I might do that some other time. UPDATE: There was still about 3 Litres of water left after the 40 mins of running.

UPDATE:

Today I put on another 4 M of copper piping, so it has a total of 12 M on the boiler and 0.75 on the way to the engine. I also sharpened the blade. In a minute, I am gonna go and make a shroud/cowling for the top of the fire box, this will make the flames get redirected over the boiler, not my hands haha.

UPDATE:

I just put the PSI gauge on to the boiler, it also has a one way valve on it, so I can fill the tank without needing to remove the gauge. I also set up a new bracket for the fire extinguisher.

UPDATE:

Shroud/Cowling done. I will run the mower 14-15 hours from now. I am planning on cutting most/all of my lawn.

UPDATE: It weighs 30 KG when loaded with water.

Read full topic
